entry.title: Classical Empires Assignment: a review of Emperor Hadrian
entry.content:
What I want to talk about today is the rule of the Roman Emperor Hadrian. Hadrian was the emperor who reigned from 117 to 138. He inherited the political legacy of his cousin, Emperor Trajan. He was listed as one of the five emperors of the Roman Empire by Edward Gibbon. Gibbon eulogizes the politics of the five emperors in his The History Of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, which is an important historical material. In ideology, he rebuilt the Pantheon and strengthened the religious stability in Rome. From the military view, he ended the endless war in the East and built Hadrian’s Wall. Economically, Britain’s agricultural production has been greatly developed under his rule. He was the first emperor to step across the territory of the empire, I believe this the trailer of the expansion of Roman identity. But he also has shortcomings. He suppressed Christianity and cannot realize that monotheism was far stronger than polytheism in maintaining the centripetal nature of the government. He is also unable to solve the political and economic crisis in Rome, and can only delay the crisis through the existing expansion results and personal prestige.

Hadrian’s inheritance of Trajan’s political legacy was not all smooth sailing, but it is clear that Hadrian solved this problem very well, although some historians suspect that Trajan may never officially designate a successor. However, the good attitude of the emperor Trajan and the queen towards Hadrian made Hadrian establish the image of Trajan’s orthodox heir in Rome. Trajan ordered Hadrian to serve as the commander of the army during several crusades, which enabled Hadrian to establish a high prestige among the eastern armies of the empire. When Trajan tragically died during the last Eastern Expedition, Hadrian was able to quickly get the support of the Queen and the Eastern Legion, forcing the Senate far away in Rome to accept the set result. Even so, there was still a political struggle in which four opposing senators were executed.

Hadrian was a very conscientious emperor. After establishing authority and legitimacy, he quickly led the Eastern Legion back to the division and presided over the political situation. Generally speaking, the core method of Emperor Hadrian’s governance of the empire and control of his own power can be summed up as defense. I think this is due to the gradual decline of the Roman slavery economy. The economic development of slave estates requires the constant supply of new slaves and uncultivated land without ownership. The empire has long achieved this goal through continuous external conquests. But as the territory of the empire expanded to a certain extent, more and more slave owners yearned for more slaves and land. But on the other hand, the harsh border environment and undeveloped land to be conquered made the empire’s expansion increasingly weak in Hadrian’s time. This contradiction caused a political crisis in the empire. The bankruptcy of the freedmen reduced the empire’s excellent reserve personnel. The political and economic crisis will soon evolve into a military conflict after the five sage emperors.

In response to this new era, Hadrian has taken a series of measures. In terms of foreign policy, Hadrian abandoned the provinces of Assyria and Mesopotamia conquered by Trajan. He eased the relationship with the Parthians and ended the long war on the Eastern battlefield. On the other hand, it brutally suppressed the Jewish Bar Kokhba revolt and changed the Jewish province to Syria and Palestine, weakening national identity and strengthening Roman rule. In the same way in the West, he built Hadrian’s Wall to prevent the Picts from invading, and alleviating the burden was internal. He promoted Greek culture, which laid the foundation for the later Hellenization of the empire.

As a connecting emperor, Hadrian successfully completed the transformation of the Roman Empire from offensive to defensive. This mysterious and contradictory emperor passed away in 138 AD. He accepted a war-torn Rome and left one behind. The culturally open empire is the epitome of the entire era of the five sage emperors.

entry.title: A Short Guide: Construct wave equation🚀
entry.content:
Wave equation

Construct wave equation

Vertical displacement function: $u(x,t)$

Mass density function: $\rho_{0}(x)$

Tension function: $T(x,t)$

Angle function: $\theta(x,t)$

Definition: Perfectly elastic string

Perfectly elastic string has the tension $T(x,t)$ is a constant $T_{0}$.

Definition: Perfectly flexible string

The force exert on every segment of perfectly flexible string is tangential, such tangential force is call tension.

Let’s try to derive the one-dimensional wave equation with the functions above.

$$\text{slope of the segment} = \dfrac{\partial u}{\partial x} = \tan \theta(x, t) = \dfrac{\sin \theta(x, t)}{\cos \theta(x, t)} \approx \sin \theta(x, t) \approx \theta(x, t).$$

It is tempting to focus on gate fidelity as the most important challenge facing neutral atom quantum computation.

Optical traps for neutral atoms cannot be arbitrarily deep.

To minimize heating and decoherence rates the traps should be designed to satisfy a ground-Rydberg magic condition.

Q&A

  • Which institutions are doing the trapped ions and which are doing the superconducting qubits? ^86f797
    • trapped ions:
    • superconducting qubits:
  • What is the DiVincenzo criteria fitting including?
    1. a scalable physical system with well characterized qubits
    2. initialization of simple fiducial states
    3. long relevant decoherence times, much longer than the gate operation
    4. an universal set of quantum gates
    5. a qubit-specific measurement capability
  • Why we are interesting in coherence times of netural atoms?
    • phase difference produces coherence, make wave phase predictable
    • quantum decoherence means reduce the decoherence between quantum system and outside envirment, resulting in classic probability mix
    • by increasing the coherence times, we reduce the rate of coherence, make measurement possible
  • In neutral atom quantum computer, how does it work?
    • array of single atom qubits in optical or magnetic traps
    • logic gates are performed with some combination of optical and microwave fields
    • array is initialized from a reservoir of laser cooled atoms
    • results are measured with resonance fluorescence
    • atom used are heavy alkalis $\mathrm{Rb}$ and $\mathrm{Cs}$
  • How many ways are there used to make entanglements?
    • atomphoton-atom coupling
    • collision
    • Rydberg interaction
  • What are the intrinsic features of neutral atoms that make them well suited for multi-qubit experiments?
    • neutral atoms are all identical so that the qubit frequency $\omega_{q}$ is the same
  • What are the natural, synthetic, identical, heterogeneous qubits?
  • What methods are used to improve qubit loading from laser cooled atoms?
  • What is the best trap depth (energy well)?
    • optical traps for neutral atoms cannot be arbitrarily deep
    • optical traps: Cs, $\lambda=1.06 \mu \mathrm{m}$, intensity $20 \mathrm{mK}$
    • magnetic traps: $6 \mathrm{~T}$, intensity $4 \mathrm{mK}$
  • Why the trap lifetime is limited?
    • heating
    • collisional loss
  • How to incease the trap lifetime?
    • reduce heating:
      • cryogenic environment
      • periodically recool trapped atoms
    • small code sizes
    • fast measurements
    • Rydberg has a long lifetimes
    • error correction
  • What is the probability of having 1 bit lost in ERROR CORRECTION?
    • $\boxed{P_{\text {loss }}=N_{\text {code }}\left(1-e^{-t / \tau_{\text {vac }}}\right) \simeq N_{\text {code }} t / \tau_{\text {vac }}}$
      • $N_{\text {code }}$: # of qubits of quantum error correcting code
      • $\tau_{\mathrm{vac}}$: vacuum limited lifetime of each qubit
      • $P_{\text {loss }}$: probability of having lost at least one bit after time $t$
    • in multiple qubits, have $\boxed{\mathcal{O}(1 / N)}$ as efficiency of loss
  • If error being correctable, how much time we need for this correction?
    • $\boxed{\tau_{\mathrm{vac}}>\frac{N_{\mathrm{code}} t_{\mathrm{qec}}}{\epsilon}}$
      • $t_{\mathrm{qec}}$: duration we require for experiments, $t_{\mathrm{qec}}=0.1 N_{\mathrm{code}}$
  • If error being correctable, how much time we need for reloading?
    • $t_{\mathrm{qec}} \geq 1 / r_{\text {load }} \Longrightarrow \boxed{r_{\text {load }}>\frac{N_{\text {phys }}}{\tau_{\text {vac }} \epsilon}}$ [[#Fig Contours labeled with tau_ mathrm vac in seconds from tau_ mathrm vac frac N_ mathrm code t_ mathrm qec epsilon]]
      • $N_{\text {phys}}=$ number of qubit processor $\times$ $N_{\text {code}}$
      • $r_{\text {load }}$: time required to reload a lost atom
  • What is the expected temperature for cryogenic environment?
  • Comparison of coherence!
    • longitudinal relaxation $\left(T_{1}\right)$
      • sensitive to: external fields > light scattering
        • magnetic fields: for qubits encoded in Zeeman substates, cause transitions between states [[#^45762f]]
          • (transitions caused by low frequency magnetic fields are negligible)
        • microwave frequency fields: transitions
          • use RF shield
      • state transition: magnetic fields and microwave frequency fields
    • transverse relaxation $\left(T_{2}\right)$
      • sensitive to: dephasing mechanisms that preserve population but randomly change the relative phase of the qubit states
      • state transition: magnetic noise, intensity noise in optical traps (Dephasing)
  • What is the Zeeman substates? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeeman_effect
    • Zeeman effect: the splitting of a spectral line into several components in the presence of an electric field
    • Zeeman sub-levels is a function of magnetic field strength
  • What are the Rydberg magic traps and Rydberg magic condition?
    • Rydberg magic traps is an optimization on avoiding heating and collison
  • What is the ponderomotive potential? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ponderomotive_force
    • the ponderomotive force is a nonlinear force that a charged particle experiences in an inhomogeneous oscillating electromagnetic field
    • over a complete cycle this makes the particle move towards the area of lesser force
  • How does the ground-Rydberg magic traps has been developed over time?
    • problem of early magic trap: required relatively small detuning, causing:
      • excessive scattering rates
      • suboptimal coherence properties
    • solving: matching of the trapping potential to the Rydberg electron wavefunction
      • Rydberg electron wavefunction: $\alpha_{\mathrm{Ryd}}=-e^{2} /\left(m \omega ^{2}\right)$
      • bounded condition $\left|\alpha_{\mathrm{Ryd}}\right|<\left|\alpha_{\text {ground }}\right|$ and $\alpha_{\text {Ryd }}, \alpha_ {\text {ground }}<0$
  • How to briefly explain the “landscape modulated” trap? Why the 3D overlap of the wavefunction with the repulsive ponderomotive potential leading to it?

entry.title: A Short Review: The topological materials and the topological order
entry.content:
From Hall Effect to topological materials

The entire field can be traced back to the earliest when the Hall effect was discovered. In 1879, Edwin Hall, a Ph.D. student at Johns Hopkins University in Maryland, discovered the Hall effect (QE). [1] This phenomenon indicates that a voltage proportional to the magnetic field will be generated in the direction perpendicular to the current and the applied magnetic field.

With the advancement of technology, the German physicist von Klitzing at Max Planck Institute discovered that when the magnetic field increases to a certain extent, the Hall voltage actually rises in steps. This is called the Integer Quantum Hall Effect (IQHE). [2] The integers appearing in the Hall effect are some topological quantum numbers, called Chern numbers. After observing a non-integer Hall voltage. The Fractional Quantum Hall Effect (FQHE) was discovered by Robert Laughlin, Daniel Tsui and others. [3][4]

In 2005, a new study guided the Quantum Spin Hall Effect (QSHE), which is essentially the quantization of the abnormal Hall effect part. [5] It brings us a new state of matter. We call them two-dimensional topological insulators (TI), and they have special edge effects: there are some special quantum states on the surface.

If one material is topologically nontrivial and another material is topologically trivial, put them together. There will be a topological phase change on the contact surface, and this phase change will have some physical phenomena: for example, the surface conductivity of topological insulators. In order to describe this phase transition, we need to find the topological invariants, such as Chern number [6] and Z2 invariant [7], or hopf fibration [8], topological order [9] and returning Thouless pump [8]. Based on Pontrjagin’s research on the dual-band Hamiltonian in the three-momentum dimension, Dr. Alexandradinata’s team studied a new topological invariant: returning Thouless pump (RTP), and did a detailed study of the Hopf-RTP relation. Generally speaking, different topological quantum states can be described by different topological invariants. Therefore, determining the topological invariant of the electronic structure of a material system is the core of judging its topological properties. [10][11] This topological invariant is closely related to Berry’s phase [12][13], so Chern–Gauss–Bonnet theorem can be a very helpful tool. [14] Dr. Alexandradinata and Dr. Syzranov of UCSC both have important contribution in this field. [15] [8] [16] Some other information that I would like to check during phd are [17][18][19]. Dr. Alexandradinata most recent reseearch[8]

Quantum Spin Liquid and topological order

“Quantum Spin Liquid” (QSL) was proposed by Anderson in a 1973 paper. In the original “Resonating Valence Bond” theory (RVB), there are some errors, so it has not received the attention it deserves. [20] After a long time, due to the discovery of high-temperature superconductivity, people renewed emphasis on quantum spin liquid, and Resonating Valence Bond and Valence Bond State (VBS) were gradually improved. [21] Spin liquid refers to spin frustration caused by a certain geometric symmetry or the complexity of interaction, a state in which a ground state presents a disordered state, including spin glass and quantum spin liquid. The biggest difference between quantum spin liquid and the former is the existence of long-range RVB. This quantum fluctuation means the existence of long-range entanglement, which is of great help to our understanding of entanglement. [24] QSL state has nothing to do with spontaneous symmetry breaking [22], so it does not involve Landau phase transition theory [23]. Our understanding of it may require a deeper understanding of topological order. This makes QSL research has great potential. The existence of long-range entanglement and strong coherence makes this field possible to lead topological quantum computing and quantum communication to make more progress in the future. This review is of great help to me in understanding the recent developments in the field of QSL research. [24] Dr. Syzranov’s paper is also helpful here. [25]

In the previous section we mentioned the idea of topological order. In 1989, Wen Xiaogang put the fractional quantum Hall state on different topological manifolds to probe the new paradigm implicit in the fractional quantum Hall state. This brings us to the concept of topological order. [26][9] Different from Landau’s symmetry breaking theory, topological order is a new state of matter. I don’t know enough about it. I will carefully drill the basic theory in the phd stage to prepare for research. Citing the original paper here. [27]

entry.title: 如何处理 err YAMLException can not read a block mapping entry;
entry.content:
creation date: 星期二 9日 十一月-2021-12:10:56
modification date: 星期日 21日 十一月-2021-23:00:45
article version: 1.0.0
tags: #Coding #Debugging

program: #hexo
bug type: #sdk_exception
template version: #coding_debug 1.0.0

README

Cover image comes from: https://cyto.top/2018/12/23/solution-hexo-can-not-read-a-block-mapping-entry/

Body

看到别人挖了一个坑，没填，我正好遇到了这个问题，于是填掉哈哈哈。

我的报错信息是这样的：

err: YAMLException: can not read a block mapping entry; a multiline key may not be an implicit key at line 2, column 5:      date:

我找到了 date 所在的位置，是 markdown 文件的开头，定义基本信息 Front-matter 的地方

---title: [Note of Phys 480] Lecture 5.2 corresponding to McIntyre Chapter 3date:update:permalink:categories:- 课程（Lecture）- 爱荷华州立（ISU）- 物理（Physics）tags: [Physics, Quantum Physics, Schrödinger Equation, Differential Equation, Spin]description:keywords:comments:layout:type:photos:link:mathjax: true---

原来是 hexo 不支持 [] 括号在文件头，Front-matter 修改成：

---title: <Note of Phys 480> Lecture 5.2 corresponding to McIntyre Chapter 3date:update:permalink:categories:- 课程（Lecture）- 爱荷华州立（ISU）- 物理（Physics）tags: [Physics, Quantum Physics, Schrödinger Equation, Differential Equation, Spin]description:keywords:comments:layout:type:photos:link:mathjax: true---

之后就问题解决了✌️

entry.title: Diagonalization method: determine a matrices being diagonalizable
entry.content:
Question

!!! info “Example Question:” Use the Diagonalization Method to determine whether each of the following matrices is diagonalizable. If so, specify the matrices $\mathbf{D}$ and $\mathbf{P}$ and check your work by verifying that $\mathbf{D}=\mathbf{P}^{-1} \mathbf{A} \mathbf{P}$. $$\star(g) \qquad \mathbf{A}=\begin{equation} \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 & 0 & 0 \ -3 & 4 & 1 \ 3 & -2 & 1 \end{array}\right] \end{equation}$$

Solution

First of all, take the characteristic polynomial of $\mathbf{A}$ and solve for eigenvalues.

$$\begin{equation} p_A(x)=|x \mathbf{I}_{n}-\mathbf{A}| &=\Bigg|\left[\begin{array}{ccc}{x} & {0} & {0} \ {0} & {x} & {0} \ {0} & {0} & {x}\end{array}\rig \left[\begin{array}{ccc}{2} & {0} & {0} \ {-3} & {4} & {1} \ {3} & {-2} & {1}\end{array}\right]\Bigg|\ &=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}{x-2} & {0} & {0} \ {3} & {x-4} & {-1} \ {-3} & {2} & {x-1}\end{array}\right|\ &=(x-2)\left|\begin{array}{ccc}{x-4} & {-1} \ {2} & {x-1}\end{array}\right|\ &=(x-2)((x-4)(x-1)-(-2))\ &=(x-2)(x^{2}-5x+4+2)\ &=(x-2)(x^{2}-5x+6)\ &=(x-2)(x-3)(x-2)=0\end{equation}$$

So, we have that the eigenvalues of $\mathbf{A}$ are $x_1=2$ and $x_2=3$. For eigenvalue $x_1=2$, have linear system:

$$\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}{2-2} & {0} & {0} & {0} \ {3} & {2-4} & {-1} & {0} \ {-3} & {2} & {2-1} & {0}\end{array}\right] \Longrightarrow \left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}{1} & {-\frac{2}{3}} & {-\frac{1}{3}} & {0} \ {0} & {0} & {0} & {0} \ {0} & {0} & {0} & {0}\end{array}\right]$$

So, we have $2$ independent eigenvectors $[1, 0, 3]$ and $[2, 3, 0]$.

And for the eigenvalue $x_2=3$, have linear system:
